fields.description: Cryptographic keys used for cookies protection should be generated uniquely per installation of the console and they should be protected from unauthorized access.
fields.summary: Handling of crypto keys for cookies (session) security

comments.body: /cc [~kdas]

Yeah this approach seems best.  We could either have the install process generate the key files or have config.py generate the key files if they don't exist (which they wouldn't upon first time running).

I'd read it from a separate file and have the init script generate it the first time it runs.  That is how things like ssh work.  Don't generate it in the install script though -- do it in the init script.  The install script runs once for everybody at packaging time, which would likely yield undesired results.  8^)

[~viglesias], what can you tell us about the init script?
[~gholms] Not much to tell as it hasnt been written. What would you like to know?
I've added a pull request for this one - https://github.com/eucalyptus/koala/pull/224

We need to make sure that session-keys.ini is only accessible (i.e., file permissions) by the console. Also, it should never be put into a predictable location (i.e., session-keys.ini) in publicly writable directory like /tmp because of potential race conditions. 

More background info on related security issues:
http://www.linuxsecurity.com/content/view/115462/151/

In the current implementation, the keys are stored in a publicly readable location /etc/eucaconsole/session-keys.ini. When creating session-keys.ini, the init script should create it with a restrictive umask to ensure that it's only readable/writable by the console.
Key file now gets created with 600 permissions - https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/456
Pull request 456 approved

Ok so I didn't have much luck with os.umask() (was getting bizarre behaviour) so I'm using os.open() instead.  Will this work?
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/517

pycrypto on centos is an older version and doesn't contain Crypto.Random, so we can't rely on that unless EPEL get's updated. Checking on getting that done. In the meantime, we'll need to keep using the standard random package. Unsure if we can get this updated in time for 4.0
If we can't use pycrypto, according to python [docs|https://docs.python.org/dev/library/random.html], other options are os.urandom() or SystemRandom.
Yep David and I just discussed using SystemRandom if that's ok.
[~Rocky], yes, AFAIK, SystemRandom should be fine.
Ok now using SystemRandom.  Please note that the default seed value used is current time.  https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/517

Based on further feedback from David, looks like we should do a check to make sure SystemRandom can be used (as the python docs says it's not available on all OS's) and then fall back to standard random.
I think we're safe with SystemRandom support, looking at http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6219254/what-platforms-offer-systemrandom
Pull request 517 approved
